educational_objective: Diagnose superficial thrombophlebitis of the great saphenous vein.
question_text: A 52-year-old man presents with pain and redness of the left medial thigh of 2 days' duration.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is superficial thrombophlebitis of the great saphenous vein (Option D). Superficial thrombophlebitis of the lower extremity may involve any superficial vein, including the great saphenous vein, the small saphenous vein, and the accessory saphenous vein. It presents with erythema, pain, and warmth along the course of the vein, sometimes with tenderness and a palpable cord. This patient has pain and erythema along the course of the great saphenous vein (which usually runs down the medial thigh, curves posteriorly into the popliteal fossa, and then continues down the medial calf) signifying likely thrombophlebitis. Ultrasonography is indicated to assess for possible concomitant deep venous thrombosis.
